fields.description:
SourceTree 2.3 crashes when the "Open Terminal..." button is clicked on the UI.

Steps to reproduce:
# Install iTerm2 or iTerm2 version3 beta
# In SourceTree preferences set iTerm2 in General -> Misc -> Terminal App
# Click on "Open Terminal..."
# Start wondering what happened! :-P

I have attached a heapdump for the same.

This affects developer workflow and ends up becoming very frustrating for those who rely on that button.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes when "Open a Terminal Window" is clicked with iTerm2 set as terminal

fields.description:
When trying to push a git-svn clone to Subversion (equivalent of {{git svn dcommit}}) SourceTree crashes 100% of the time just as the push sheet is appearing. This has only started happening since upgrading to 2.3.

Please see the attached crash report.
fields.summary: Crash when pushing to Subversion

fields.description:
The Help menu shows that cmd+o should open the browser but instead it opens a window for opening a repository.

Clicking the 'Show Repository Browser' item in the menu however opens the browser as expected.
fields.summary: cmd+b no longer opens the repository browser

fields.description: When I Choose my terminal To iTerm2, then I click the Terminal icon on the window, It crash
fields.summary: Crash on click Terminal When switch Terminal to iTerm2

fields.description:
When applying a stashed change, esp. when enabling the "delete after applying" option, we loose the information expressed in the stash message. This information will usually describe the stashed change. Thus, in many cases, the developer will want this very message (or a slight variation of it) to become the next commit message.

I'd suggest that SourceTree adds the message of each applied Stash to the current commit message (without committing the changes, just like it is happening now).
fields.summary: applying a stash should prepopulate the commit message with the stash message

fields.description: See http://pastebin.com/DTve3e47
fields.summary: BETA 2.3 Crash report on Startup

fields.description:
After updating to 2.2.4, Sourcetree is now maddeningly difficult to read the log view because the font is too small on anything but a very low-resolution monitor.

This issue has been opened before at least twice, and yet Atlassian continues to disregard the problem that your users are clearly experiencing, based on comment traffic.

Marking an issue DUPLICATE and RESOLVED is not solving the problem for your users.

Rather it sends a strong "WE DON'T CARE" message.

Is this the official Atlassian position on user support as far as accessibility issues go?
fields.summary: Make an option to adjust Log View Font Size

fields.description:
Sort order of Tree view does not match with diff view.
See attached screenshot.
fields.summary: Sort order of Tree view does not match with diff view

fields.description:
h4. Steps To Reproduce
# Rebase a branch that causes a conflict mid-rebase
# Resolve the conflict
# Click the Commit button in the top menu
# When given the option to "Continue," "Abort," or "Cancel," either select "Cancel" or type "Escape" to stop any further action

h4. Expected Results
The dialog should close and no action should be taken.

h4. Actual Results
The rebase is aborted as if the "Abort" button was pressed.
fields.summary: Cancelling Rebasing From The Continue Rebase Dialog Aborts The Rebase Entirely

fields.description:
SourceTree is unable to perform most tasks on files when using the {{core.worktree}} config option to redirect the location of the working copy away from the location of the git repo. This is useful for example when you want to track your HOME dir in a git repo, but locate the git repo itself in another subpath in order to avoid having any git commands outside any other git repo defaulting to this HOME dir git repo by accident.

For example, you might do the following:
{noformat}
git init ~/repos/homedir
cd ~/repos/homedir
git config core.worktree ../../
git add ../../.bash_profile
{noformat}

Notice how the {{git add}} command needs to point at the actual relative location of the file. This is the path that will also show when you run {{git status}}, however if you run {{git status --porcelain}} then the {{../../}} prefix is not displayed, showing the path relative to the worktree, not the location of the git repo. Since SourceTree uses the {{\-\-porcelain}} option, using those file paths directly in other git commands fails with {{pathspec did not match any files}} kind of errors.

In order to fix this usage scenario SourceTree needs to detect the {{core.worktree}} setting and adjust paths accordingly.
fields.summary: SourceTree doesn't support Git repo with core.worktree set

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*
1. Create a branch with a long name. E.g: branch with long name: "feature/XXX-XXXX_Due_Date_option_is_not_highlighted_in_form_for_new_Task_creation_when_Due_Date_is_cleared
2. Stage a file and press commit
3. Commit button on bottom right looks to be truncated.
fields.summary: "Commit" button becomes truncated if branch name is too long

fields.description:
Actions with a confirmation popup are displaying it on one line only, without possibility to resize or scroll, causing really long popups.

Steps to reproduce:
1) attempt to reset to a commit with a long message
fields.summary: Confirmation Popups are not resizable/scrollable and cause kilometric display

After updating to the latest version of SourceTree (v2.2+) I can no longer figure out how to display the status bar.  This is hiding previously useful information, especially whether I am working on a detached head in a child project.
I now am forced to attempt to check in a change before I am aware that I've become detached, whereas previously this information was available at a glance.

fields.description:
When applying a stash in source tree, there is a modal dialog that asks whether to delete the stash after applying. I propose adding another option called "Delete after applying, if no conflicts". 

This makes it more reassuring that the stash is not needed when applying it causes no merge conflicts to resolve.
fields.summary: Add a new option when applying stash, "Delete after applying, if no conflicts"

fields.description:
SourceTree is not refreshing commits within submodules automatically. That means it highlights a different commit (e.g.from previously checked out branch) instead of the current commit the submodule is pointing to.

After forcing the refresh (Cmd + R) it updates and displays the correct commit hash as selected. Same goes for restarting the app.

Same applies for the (BETA version as well (2.2.5).
fields.summary: SourceTree is not refreshing commits within submodules automatically.

fields.description:
Command + B used to open/bring to front the Repository Browser; this shortcut no longer works.

Best workaround I've found so far is to use Command + N and then close the contextual menu.
fields.summary: Command + B no longer opens Repository Browser

fields.description:
When merging a branch into e.g. master, I hit the Merge button. Then, to quickly find the latest commit on the branch which is to be merged, I use the top-left filter to filter on that branch.

When we decide to remove the branch after merging, an error message is raised with the following text:

'git log' failed with code 128:'fatal: bad revision 'aaaa'
'

where aaaa is the name of the branch which was just removed. This message keeps showing up every x seconds, probably because of auto refreshes.

When clicking Merge again and unset the filter on the branch (which actually doesn't exist anymore), the error messages disappear.

To summarize, these instructions can be followed to reproduce:

- switch to master
- create a branch, e.g. aaaa
- commit anything to that branch
- switch back to master
- click Merge
- filter on branch aaaa in the dialog where you pick the commit to merge
- cancel merge (or go ahead with the merge, doesn't matter)
- remove branch aaaa (force if you cancelled the merge)

To get rid of the messages:
- click Merge
- filter on branch 'All branches'
fields.summary: Merge branch dialog branch filter raises errors when the selected branch gets deleted

fields.description: It would be nice if SourceTree could show subrepositories under repository in Start Window liuke what TortoiseHg does.
fields.summary: Show subrepository a repository in Start Window

fields.description:
Create a git project with atleast one more branch other than master.
Try to clone the project from URL 
Enter the project URl and try to expand the advance options. 

Expected Result: 
Advance option as like versions before should show branch to be selected and other advance options.

Actual Result:
Advance option does not expand and shows no advance options.
fields.summary: Advance options does not expand while cloning a project from URL

fields.summary: Source 2.2.4 suffers from intermittent  crashes during pull or push

fields.description:
Select a changed, unstaged file with more than one line or hunk changed.
Select a changed line or hunk in the diff view and stage it. The diff view follows the line/hunk into the "staged files" section. 
So now if you want to stage a new change from the same file, you have to manually look for the file and scroll to the point you were in. This is needless legwork.

Ideally, the diff view should just stay were it is while staging, so one can continue reviewing and staging more changes.

This is uncomfortable enough that I prefer going into git-cola just for staging changes.
fields.summary: Staging a change makes difficult to stage more changes

fields.description:
When I pull new changes for a submodule, I get a change entry for that submodule in the containing repository. Then when I stage that, I need to remember why I'm even pulling in these changes to compose the commit message.

It would be great if SourceTree could grab the commit messages for that range and pre-fill my commit message field with them.

Or offer to grab them, like when I merge in changes and it offers to paste in the merged commits' messages. SourceTree knows the current and new hash already (it shows it for the change entry, after all).
fields.summary: If a commit tracks a submodule, offer to insert the commit messages from the submodule
Filtered TAGS list

fields.description:
*Reproduction steps*

1. When a rebase is in progress, click the "Commit" toolbar button
2. On the "Rebase In Progress" dialog, click the "Cancel" button

*Expected*

The dialog dismisses, and the rebase is left in its previous state.

*Observed*

The rebase is aborted.
fields.summary: Cancel button on "Rebase In Progress" dialog aborts the rebase

Login required for: https://bitbucket.org

SourceTree asks me to authenticate each time I start it. After entering my bitbucket password I am able to access my bitbucket projects. Each time I authenticate in this way the Mac System Console shows the following error:

5/2/16 4:08:04.167 PM SourceTree[20439]:  SecOSStatusWith error:[-34018] Error Domain=NSOSStatusErrorDomain Code=-34018 "client has neither application-identifier nor keychain-access-groups entitlements" UserInfo={NSDescription=client has neither application-identifier nor keychain-access-groups entitlements}
fields.summary: SourceTree for Mac asks for Bitbucket Password after each start

fields.summary: Fabric Crash #4 - doMenuItemCustomTitles

fields.description:
The performance of Mercurial is extremely "laggy" compared with Git. Doing pretty much any operation with a Mercurial repo causes the application to essentially "lock up" but this is particularly noticeable on the "history" screen when clicking between commits, doing merges, etc... 

I have Tortoisehg installed on the same machine and this doesn't have the same lagginess at all on the same repos.

As requested by Brian Ganninger I have attached a sample from the app which was taken while clicking between items in the history of a repo.
fields.summary: Mercurial Lag

fields.description:
Hi,


I was wondering if SourceTree for Mac supported Korean. SourceTree for Windows supports Korean, and 89% of Mac version's string is already translated( https://www.transifex.com/atlassian/sourcetree-for-mac/ ).

If SourceTree for Mac supports Korean, then all of our designers who are not familiar with English and engineering will be VERY happy, because they're having difficulties in using SourceTree.
fields.summary: Korean locale support, please!

fields.description:
If you have a Git message template (`commit.template`), the expected behavior when starting a commit is for the cursor to be at the top, with the template below. This is what happens, e.g., if using `VIM` with `git commit` on the CLI.

In Mac SourceTree Version 2.2.4 (57), with such a template, not only is my cursor placed at the bottom, but the scroll bar is still at the top, so the cursor is hidden.

The cursor should be placed at the top.
fields.summary: Incorrect cursor position when using Git commit message template

fields.description:
For quick stashes, I often create stashes with common names, such as "stash".

When I get a name collision (a stash called "stash" already exists), the SourceTree prompt says:

 > A stash with this name already exists.

 > Do you want to create a new stash with the same name? Your existing stash will not be overwritten.

See pics.

I *do* want to create a NEW stash with the SAME NAME. So I click "OK".

EXPECTED:

 - The prompt behaves as it says it will. Namely: 
 - Creates a new stash with the same name.
 - The existing stash named "stash" is not deleted
 - Changes are stashed. Working copy is clean.


ACTUAL
 - Creation of the stash fails.
 - New stash "stash" is not created.
 - My working copy is still there. Changes are not stashed.
 - I'm forced to type a unique name, rather than "stash".

This is a *regression in SourceTree 2*. In SourceTree 1, I was able to create multiple stashes with the same name.
fields.summary: Cannot create Stash with same name as existing Stash.

fields.description:
I often want to tell other developers on my team to look at or pull a specific branch. I'll send this branch's text name via email or chat.

This requires me to type out the branch name. If the branch name is long or complicated, typing it out is very annoying:


{code:java}
/features/image_carousel/improvement_to_scrolling_hotpatch
{code}

The Branch Sidebar's right-click menu should be given a *"Copy Branch Name to Clipboard"* option. This option will copy the branch's name to your clipboard.

You can then paste the complicated branch name into your email or chat program.

This would be similar to the "Copy SHA-1 to Clipboard" option when right-clicking a commit. Extremely useful command in both cases.
fields.summary: "Copy Branch Name to Clipboard" right-click option for sending branch info to coworkers

fields.description:
As of today, there is no way to reorder the branch in your branch list. It is sorted alphabetically. (see attachment).

It would be nice to be able to reorder that list in order to, for instance, always keep master on top/bottom.

That could be done by a drag and drop on that list.
fields.summary: Ability to reorder the branch list

fields.description:
Add the ability to disable the pull and push preview screens so that the pull and push is simply just done and you don't have to wait and click again to actually do the pull. 

I can see that this would either be done via options in the preferences or via different buttons that could be added to the toolbar allowing them to either replace the existing buttons or be there in addition to the existing buttons.
fields.summary: Ability to disable pull and push preview screen

fields.description:
We have nested submodules and it would be nice if they could be supported in the same way as submodules are when it comes to guarding against accidental commits in the parent project (The dialog warning you that you have uncommitted changes in your submodule).

If I use git status in the root then it will show me changes even in recursive submodules so the data should be available.
fields.summary: Status for recursive submodules

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*
1. Commit a file with filename which contains a non-ascii character (for example: muñoz.t) into a repo and push it to a remote.
2. Clone the repo on Sourcetree
3. The file with the character will show as unstaged
fields.summary: Cloning a repo which contains files with certain non-ascii characters filename will unstage the file

fields.description:
As a developer
I want a prompt or input for JIRA task IDs when I commit to git/hg
So that I am reminded to link my commits to JIRA tasks

This is a feature that exists in most SVN clients (ex: TortoiseSVN for Windows). Having this prompt helps teams remember to link their commits to JIRA IDs.

From Atlassian Answer: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/38510430/answers/38510499
fields.summary: Prompt for JIRA IDs on commit

fields.description: I am not able to commit my changes anymore to my branch. This is because the buttons are hidden and not clickable when the branch name is too long.
fields.summary: Not able to commit changes due to long branch name

fields.description:
It would be very useful if there were some form of indicator(icon, etc) that shows next to the name of a local branch whenever it has a corresponding remote branch.

When we branch for bugs or features we end up doing PRs on github that end with someone merging them and deleting the branch. With this new requested indicator, it would be much easier to see within the source tree UI when those branches are merged and deleted from the remote repo so that they can safely be cleaned up locally as well.
fields.summary: Show indicator when local branch is backed by remote branch
Respect PATH when running Git hooks

fields.description:
Now that I have turned on GPG signing of commits in git, I have come across the annoyance that the "Sign Commit" option in the commit window is not sticky.  I will turn it on, but it is not remembered when I exit and restart SourceTree for that repository.

Fortunately,  I have "[commit] gpgsign = true" in my .gitconfig which causes the commit to fail unless it is signed.  Otherwise, I would constantly be failing to sign my commits.

It should also be more visible in the commit window as to whether or not the "Sign Commit" flag is turned on or off.
fields.summary: "Sign Commit" under commit options is not sticky

fields.description: My repo contains some branchs, and branch view shows all branchs in default. So I set the option to current branch that branch view only tracks the branch I lived. However I checkout other branch back and forth, the option value restored automatically! Thus, I have to change the option value again and again!
fields.summary: Branch view's option `current branch` should be kept always except for user changed the option value!

fields.description:
When I try to merge a branch with a merge-commit (--no-ff) using SourceTree, the merge crashes with the following error message:

{{gpg: cannot open `/dev/tty': Device not configured
error: gpg failed to sign the data
fatal: failed to write commit object}}

Merging using the command line {{git merge --no-ff branchname}} works fine. If you need more information, please ask me. I try to provide everything you need to fix this bug.
fields.summary: Merging branches with a signed merge-commit crashes

fields.description:
When SourceTree shows this popup:
!popup.png|thumbnail! 
and the user answers "Yes", *SourceTree blindly calls "git-lfs init" without verifying if it actually worked*. 

And when it doesn't, that's really bad because the user thinks git-lfs is up & running, but end up successfully pushing OID files *without* those files being uploaded to the LFS server (causing a lot of pain and headache in the team).

The scenario that is causing "git-lfs update" to fail is when the .git/hooks/pre-push file already exists, even if the file is actually empty -- which is our case here (we don't know why though, and it happens once in a while).

h4. Scenario to reproduce

Create an empty *pre-push* hook:
{code}
rm .git/hooks/pre-push
touch .git/hooks/pre-push
{code}

Manually call the git-lfs update:
{code}
git-lfs update
Hook already exists: pre-push

Run `git lfs update --force` to overwrite this hook.
{code}

h4. Proposed solution

After the user answered YES to the popup, SourceTree should verify if the "git-lfs update" worked. If not, then I propose that SourceTree shows another popup asking if the user wants to FORCE the update. Then if the user answered NO or if the FORCE did not work (for some reason), then inform again the user that he has *not* a working LFS environment.
fields.summary: Git LFS initialization not working in some cases

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce: 

1) Start the game
2) Click a cube in the vicinity of the player quad to "dig" the dirt cube.
3) Move to the player into the newly  "created" empty space. 
4) once the player enters, they will get stuck to the dirt cube underneath them.
fields.summary: Player gets stuck on dirt cubes after a dirt cube is deleted.

fields.description: Since the app has the availability to configure GPG keys and allow signing commits, it should also have the option to sign the actions. Neither cherry-pick, revert-commit, merge-commit nor rebases are signed again. Each of this actions destroy (obviously) the signed commits, but will not create new ones.
fields.summary: Enabling GPG signing has no effect for actions like cherry-pick, merge, revert-commit

fields.description:
I had already reported that in the group some days ago, now filed as a bug here (sorry for the delay).

I had configured SourceTree 2 (stable) generating GPG signatures and it works when preparing a commit (check "Sign commit"). However, the same steps in the beta does not work anymore. 

Perhaps a problem with the space?

{code}
credential.helper=sourcetree -c "gpg.program=/Applications/SourceTree\ Beta.app/Contents/Resources/bin/stgpg.sh" commit -q --gpg-sign=XYZ -F /var/folders/94/csb3hy6d1157wgd2mygd37rm0000gn/T/SourceTreeTemp.NNgdRP 
error: cannot run /Applications/SourceTree\ Beta.app/Contents/Resources/bin/stgpg.sh: No such file or directory
error: could not run gpg.
fatal: failed to write commit object
Completed with errors, see above
{code}
fields.summary: Could not sign with GPG

fields.description:
While using SourceTree, the view will occasionally spontaneously change, disrupting my workflow.  This change in view seems to be precipitated by the software (not by user input) by spontaneously moving the selected commit from where I'm working ("Uncommitted changes") to the most recent commit and displaying the History screen.

In the attached animated GIF, you can see how this is an issue while reviewing changes and staging them.  After a hunk is staged, the most recent commit is spontaneously selected.  In this GIF, this happens three times in a row.  Then, on the 4th hunk, the view changes spontaneously even before I click the "Stage hunk" button (it changes just after I click on the "email" folder).

However, this isn't the only case in which the bug occurs.  One of the more annoying instances is that occasionally, it will select the most recent commit *while I'm typing a commit message on the commit screen*.  This is very frustrating as my hands are on they keyboard, mid-sentence, entering a commit message.  To get back, I need to get back into the commit screen, ensure the cursor is at the correct location in the commit text, and then resume typing... at which point, sometimes SourceTree will select the most recent commit one or two more times, each time kicking me out from the Commit screen, back to the History screen.

My guess is that there's something funky going on with SourceTree's file modification detector thinking that changes have been made, and that the History tab needs to be shown again.  The main reason I guess this is that the "spinning wheel" that shows when files are being checked for changes appears reliably every time before I'm kicked out back to the History screen and the most recent commit.

This issue has been happening for many (3-6) months.  I've continued to use SourceTree since I figured the bug would be addressed in an upcoming update.  However, this bug persists.  Unfortunately, this bug is frustrating enough that if it can't be resolved, I'll likely move to another Git GUI.
fields.summary: Scans for file changes change view unnecessarily and disrupt workflow

fields.description: When the name of a branch is quite long and the sourcetree window is on a small screen, the commit and cancel buttons shrink down to the point where they cant be clicked. Surely the text of the branch name should instead be clipped at the end? This is fixed by making the window bigger on a larger screen.
fields.summary: Commit button disappearing on small screens

fields.description:
By default git status list files that have been added, deleted, or modified on top of files that are not tracked. It would save me a lot of time If the unstaged frame listed these files on top of files that are not tracked. I have many files that for various reasons can not be ignored. It is very hard to find the files I have modified so that I can add them to staging. Please see attached screen shot

Kind regards

Andy

$ git status
On branch fixTempTables
Your branch is ahead of 'origin/master' by 1 commit.
  (use "git push" to publish your local commits)
Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)

	modified:   njuryClassifier.ipynb



sdkls
fields.summary: list added, deleted, and modified files first in "unstaged" window

fields.description:
When selecting the file status view to prepare a commit the modified files do not appear in either panel (Staged files/Unstaged files). If I switch to a different view and back to file status then the files appear in the panels. However, when I click the check box to stage a file, they disappear again from both panels. The file does get staged (verified with sorcerer 2.2.4) but is not visible.

The attached image shows that there is a changed file but that it is not visible in either pane.
fields.summary: Unstaged files invisible in file status view

fields.description:
When selecting items on the side navigation the highlighted item fails to change in a consistent manner. For example when moving from "File status" to "History", the File Status item remains highlighted (see attached).

Additionally the highlight color of white on the grey background is extremely difficult to see.
fields.summary: Navigation highlighting doesn't change when selecting new item

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Have a git repository with multiple branches
2. Attempt to cherry-pick a commit from another branch that causes a conflict
3. Resolve all conflicted files
4. Attempt to commit again

What was expected:
The commit box would have the description of the cherry-picked commit, like when you do a merge commit, or even when you use `git commit` again from the command line.

What happens:
The commit box is blank and you have to re-type the message (or use `git commit` from the command line).
fields.summary: commit messages are not saved after a conflict with any cherry picked commit

fields.description: GitKraken now has a fuzzy finder. I think it's a pretty cool idea that would work really well in SourceTree.
fields.summary: Quick Command Entry Dialog

fields.description:
It appears that there are memory leaks or some other causes for SourceTree becoming slower and slower to the point where it takes 3+ seconds to CMD Tab to source tree before it reacts.
Restarting SourceTree brings back the performance up to normal, therefore I assume that this is caused by a memory leak.
This is my setup
I have probably 40 local repositories in my bookmarks view.
I have switched "auto refresh every x minutes" to off (since with so many repositories this setting doesn't make any sense)
some of my managed repositories are VERY large (millions of LOCs), one of them is always opened
I hardly reboot my machine so SourceTree keeps running for days/weeks at a time
After a couple of days of leaving SourceTree running it starts to deteriorate in performance.
fields.summary: Memory Leak / Sourcetree becoming slower and slower over time

fields.description: In the SourceTree app, the circles don't explain what is going on 100% unless you remember the color coding or click through into the project viewer. In my example, I have 3 local changes and 1 commit to be pushed upstream. Numbered cueballs are not self-explanatory.
fields.summary: Add arrows to up/down pending changes

fields.description: Sourcetree beta 1 crashes on launch while attempting to open an existing git repository. Crashlog has been appended. This is not a new bug but I am attaching it to the beta tree.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes on launch

fields.description:
The current left-hand nav UI makes it pretty much impossible to assess what stashes you have, especially when using git flow - there's simply not enough width to show things.

I know you've had this drive to declutter, but some might be needed for this.

Suggestions:

- put stashes on 2 lines: title then branch
- show stashes as part of the branches tab, beneath a branch
- redesign the main view for stashes, so the files are perhaps listed in a 2nd left hand panel 
- add a stash popup that makes it easier to see things (this would also allow you to compare the current stash to the current branch
- have a stash bin pop up from the bottom

I don't think these are all good suggestions, but just getting them out there :)
fields.summary: Improve cramped stash view

fields.description:
I can't browse my github repositories with my gihub account through source tree when trying to add a git subtree to a repository.

I have GitHub 2FA turned on. Turning it off is not an option. The account is configured to use ssh within source tree, and I have SSH keys set up correctly : regular git operations work through source tree interacting with github.
fields.summary: GitHub 2-Factor Authentication not supported when trying to browse repositories to link as a subtree

fields.description:
{code:bash}
Apr 17 20:38:34 iMac-Maxim smd[3937]: App "com.torusknot.SourceTreeNotMAS" did not pass helper check "com.atlassian.SourceTreePrivilegedHelper2".

fields.description: Since version 1.2, there has been a {{Stash}} button, but no way to undo it. The only way is to run {{git stash pop}} from the command line.
fields.summary: Cannot undo Stash

fields.description:
You need: ST with a Github account already set up.

- Right-click the "remotes" header on a new Git repository (or one that doesn't have a remote yet).
- Choose "New Remote..."
- Enter "origin" as the name, then click the globe to get the list of repositories.
- Click "Create New Repository..." in the repository sheet and create a new Github repository with a name and description.
- Now that the "Create New Repository..." sheet has closed, look for your new repository

Result:
- Newly created repository is not in the list
- You have to click "Refresh" to actually get the repo to show

Expected Result:
- SourceTree should automatically refresh the repository list as it knows a new one has just been created. It even knows what name it should have, after all. Ideally, it would even pre-select the new repository for me.
fields.summary: When creating a new remote on Github, ST doesn't automatically refresh the list.

fields.description:
When exporting a patch from one repo and importing it into another (in a different branch), I have to almost always use the command line and add {{--ignore-whitespace}} for it to apply. This is after performing a dry-run and having that succeed.

This is extremely frustrating as it just breaks the flow/process of using the UI and coding. Always I have this intermediate interruption of going to Windows Explorer, finding the repo, opening the shell, etc.

It would be great to beef up the Apply Patch dialog to support the ability to ignore whitespace.
fields.summary: Provide a way to ignore whitespace when applying a patch

fields.description:
A repo that I have successfully used as a submodule on another project now fails when I try to attach it. Everything is bitbucket repos, so authentication for a submodule within a repo that is from the same bitbucket account doesn't make sense. I just checked out that repo a moment before I tried to add the submodule. 

Also, the error mentions looking for files within the local folder of what appears to be Manjunath Basaralu Srinivasa's computer.
fields.summary: submodules now fails (and is looking for one of your dev's local folder)

fields.description:
From issue: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-4215

"The SourceTree app crashes multiple times a day (often twice in a hour) for no obvious reasons.

I've attached my bug-report and hope you can get som informations from it .

Kind regards, lukas"
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes very often

fields.description:
h3. Summary
SourceTree is crashing with a specific repo possibly because of symlinks.

h3. Environment
SourceTree Mac 2.2.3 and 2.2.4

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Download example.zip from this link: https://www.dropbox.com/s/07m5soqt0n8nbvv/example.zip?dl=0
# Unzip example.zip to *example*
# Go to SourceTree >> New repository >> Add existing local repository
# As a path for the local repository, add the path to *validate_drp* (directory inside *example*)
# Note that at the same level with validate_drp folder, there's a file named 849375p.fits.fz. Don't delete that, there's a symlink from inside the repo to that file.
# Open the repo in SourceTree
# While you are in {{History view}}, select {{Uncommitted changes}} in the graph
# After a few seconds, SourceTree hangs
 
h3. Notes
It is uncertain what is causing SourceTree to hang.
Removing the symlink outside the repo seems to solve the issue.
However, removing some other files from the repo (without removing the symlink) solves the issue as well.
fields.summary: SourceTree is crashing with a specific repo possibly because of symlinks

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Sometimes, when clicking on the checkbox next to a file or directory in the "Unstaged Files" panel, the checkbox check themselves, but the file(s) don't move to "Staged Files", they just stay in unstaged. 

h3. Environment
SourceTree Mac 2.2.3 - 2.2.4

h3. Notes
This behavior does not seem to be specific to specific file type or to specific repository.
We have not been able to reproduce it yet.
fields.summary: Clicking files' checkboxes in 'Unstages files' panel, sometimes does not stage files

fields.description: Users cannot complete installing SourceTree but they get stuck in account settings. See also the attached. It happens on any version of SourceTree WIN and MAC.
fields.summary: Cannot complete the installation but get stuck in account setting

fields.description:
SourceTree is neigh on unusable these days (has been for several versions), because it segfaults about once in every 2-10 operations.  Operations include:
* Install command line tool (this is super reliable, crashes like 99% of the time when I try this)
* Add file to index
* Commit
* Probably lots of others.  It's like just about any time you click the mouse in the UI.

Looking at the crash log, it seems to ALWAYS occur while decoding a JPEG it's fetched over the network or something (see crash file attached)

Using tcpdump/tcpflow and watching the network requests, it looks like the JPEGs in question are being fetched from gravatar.com; when I fetch the URLs manually the JPEGs look just fine, so not sure why it'd be causing the failures.
fields.summary: OS X SourceTree constantly crashing while fetching Gravatar images

fields.description:
Supernice software you're doing there!
It would be great to be able to navigate the Repository browser solely by keyboard:

scenario:

1. open Repo Browser (cmd-b)
2. Filter field selected, start typing repo name
3. list of filtered repos appears
4. [not yet working] with arrow keys (up, down), select repo to open
5. [not yet working] open selected repo with shortcut (e.g. cmd-o)
fields.summary: keyboard navigation in Repository Browser

fields.description:
`rebase` has been translated to a wrong term `衍合`, now it has been fixed to `变基`, so please udpate Chinese(China) translation in next update.
Both of SourceTree for Mac and SourceTree for Windows need update.

Reference:
https://github.com/progit/progit2-zh/blob/master/TRANSLATION_NOTES.asc
fields.summary: wrong Chinese localization: Rebase

fields.description:
files in a project which are symbolic links (as in the case of CocoaPod GoogleMaps.FrameWorks/GoogleMaps.framework/GoogleMaps or Headers or Resources … which points to Versions/A etc.. cause SourceTree to sit there and spin when trying to Add to Index of the repo commit .. as you can see in the attached .. the files which are symbolic links when i click on one of them in the add screen all i get is a non-responsive ui and a spinning happy wheel :P and i've tried this many times before and after reboots and tons of disk space everything is perfect.

How to replicate: 

Start a new app product in Xcode. Add the Google GoogleMapsCocoaPod with a pod file of: source 'https://github.com/CocoaPods/Specs.git'
platform :ios, '8.1'
pod 'GoogleMaps'

and once that is added you will see it makes a folder structure that has symbolic links to headers, etc.

try to add one of the files from the GoogleMaps cocoa pod and you will have the spinner of death forever and be hung.
fields.summary: SourceTree hangs when adding to commit Index..

fields.description: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-1791 - This talks about moving untracked files to trash instead of removing them from disk permanently. Adding to this, supporting undo/redo of this action  will be quite handy.
fields.summary: Add undo/redo support for remove untracked files

fields.description:
When git recongizes added file as 'copied', SourceTree does not show the diff and can't unstage the file. The File status view then can't refresh when I change the staged files from command-line etc. – I have to reopen the repository window.

When I unstage the file git consider to be original, I can then unstage the 'copied' file but it does not work the other way around.

This is what Git status show in terminal:
{code}
$ git status
On branch test
Your branch is ahead of 'origin/test' by 2 commits.
  (use "git push" to publish your local commits)
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git reset HEAD <file>..." to unstage)

	modified:   src/test/java/cz/test/MyClass.java
	copied:     src/test/java/cz/test/MyClass.java -> src/test/java/cz/test/OtherClass.java{code}
fields.summary: SourceTree can't handle 'copied' Git file status

fields.description:
Every time I open SourceTree, I get a login prompt for BitBucket. The _Save password in your keychain_ checkbox is checked by default, but it never appears to get saved.

 !image-2016-04-07-23-22-19-845.png! 

At this prompt I am able to log in normally and continue to use the app without any further issues - until the next time I open the app.

I reported this issue to you via Twitter, after which [I was advised to log it in Jira|https://twitter.com/rchhabs/status/717444877210914816].

Cheers,
Jono Hayward
fields.summary: Bitbucket login prompt appears every time SourceTree is opened

fields.description:
Got this from a support ticket:

{noformat}
You should have a special button for removing Git LFS from a repository.

You currently have a "Git LFS > Initialize Repository", and now I can't
push my repository because of this initialization, so nothing more fair to
have a "Git LFS > Remove from Repository" or something like it. Fortunately
google helps on finding out how to remove it, but still yous should make it.
{noformat}

Seems if the repo has no ability to have Git LFS, it will become unusuable via https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-4201
fields.summary: Remove Git LFS from repository

fields.description:
First off let me start by saying that I love the submodule functionality and it works great except for one minor gripe:

I have a submodule in which I've created a branch, made a commit to that branch and I'm now getting ready to push my parent repository's commits. In this case Sourcetree will let me push my changes fine and when Bamboo checks them out it complains that the referenced commit in the submodule does not exist (Because I forgot to push it).

Had the branch in the submodule been a remote tracking branch then Sourcetree would have warned me that I'm about to push changes in the parent repo without pushing the submodule. It would be great to have similar functionality for when branches are newly created.
fields.summary: Check submodule push status even if branch is new

fields.description:
I have a local branch that track a non-origin remote

$ git status -b --porcelain
 bengyee-BugFix-245-Missing-Checked-In-Visitors...bengyee/BugFix-245-Missing-Checked-In-Visitors [ahead 1]

But when I try to push a commit, it will go to origin/bengyee-BugFix-245-Missing-Checked-In-Visitors instead of bengyee/BugFix-245-Missing-Checked-In-Visitors

See attached screenshots.
fields.summary: SourceTree push does not respect remote branch tracking

fields.description:
SourceTree's commit message does not show leading whitespace.

Take a lot at the actual commit message:

!commandline-leading-whitespace.png|thumbnail! 

The leading whitespace is not showing in SourceTree's commit message:

!sourcetree-leading-whitespace.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: SourceTree's commit message does not show leading whitespace.

fields.description: Git flow window/popup size is not enought large. You cannot read the button label, the only solution is to use the menu "Repository > Git flow ..." If I click on this button, a new window is opened, but in french translation, the labels on button are too large (the width of the window is too small).
fields.summary: Git flow window size in french

fields.description:
When adding a BitBucket Server account (by going to the "SourceTree" window's "Remote" tab and there from the action menu choosing "Settings..."), The text field behind the "Host" popup should ignore trailing slashes. I.e. if I enter https://example.com/bitbucketserver/ it will fail. If I delete the trailing slash, it works.

SourceTree should automatically remove the slash if it is there, as it's such a common thing to do, and is actually how the server shows up. Even better would be if SourceTree spent some effort on trying to decode any Bitbucket Server server's URL, e.g. by removing the /projects/BLAH/ portion from a URL or the like.
fields.summary: Ignore excess trailing slashes on Bitbucket Server URLs

fields.description:
When I've had a conflict after merging and try to fix it, I sometimes need to start over. SourceTree provides no way at all to abort the merge. Currently, I have to resort to Terminal or add a custom action for "git merge --abort".

In general, merging could use a few more context-sensitive buttons that pop up when the MERGE_HEAD exists to perform common actions and to make it more obvious a merge is in progress.

Maybe even a banner, like what some clients show when you're on a detached head.
fields.summary: Add an "abort merge" button when a MERGE_HEAD exists

fields.description: It would be nice to be able to create bundles by selecting some commits using the UI, rather than having to use the command line.
fields.summary: Provide UI support for the mercurial bundle / unbundle commands

fields.description:
Users with the username that has "@" cannot clone a repository.

For example, if you have a username in this format - 'user@group':

#1 Login works fine via SourceTree.
#2 Cloning has an error instead - it comes up as 'user@host/path', ie without the '@group' part. 

The workaround is to fix the URL to this: 'user%40group@host/path'.

SourceTree should at least detect the "@" symbol, and auto-convert to "%40".
fields.summary: Username with "@" not accepted; will need to be replaced by "%40"
Reset to Commit on deleted file in past commit when path no longer exists fails

fields.description:
h3. Summary
"Open Recent" menu from the Sourcetree menubar doesn't do anything
 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Go to File -> Open Recent, and try to open a recently opened repo from there

h3. Expected Results
The repo opens from the 'Open Recent' menu

h3. Actual Results
Trying to open a repo from the 'Open Recent' menu doesn't do anything

h3.Workaround
Clearing the Sourcetree preferences seems to fix the issue
fields.summary: "Open Recent" doesn't do anything

fields.description:
h3. Summary
"Open Recent" menu from the Sourcetree menubar doesn't do anything
 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Go to File -> Open Recent, and try to open a recently opened repo from there

h3. Expected Results
The repo opens from the 'Open Recent' menu

h3. Actual Results
Trying to open a repo from the 'Open Recent' menu doesn't do anything

h3.Workaround
Clearing the Sourcetree preferences seems to fix the issue
fields.summary: "Open Recent" doesn't do anything
